data.title: Disarium Numbers
data.statement:
Given an integer, [[n]], you must discern if it is a <<Disarium Number>>.

Disarium Numbers are numbers where the sum of each digit raised to the power of its place in the number (read from left to right) is <<equal>> to the number itself.

An example of this is the number <<135>>:

There is a 1 in the <<first>> place.
There is a 3 in the <<second>> place.
There is a 5 in the <<third>> place.

<<(1^1 + 3^2 + 5^3) = 135>>

testCases.title: Test 2
testCases.testOut: No, 80 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testOut: No, 800 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Test 5
testCases.testOut: No, 31 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Validator 5
testCases.testOut: No, 13 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Test 6
testCases.testOut: No, 100 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Validator 6
testCases.testOut: No, 1000 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Test 7
testCases.testOut: No, 555 is not a Disarium Number.

testCases.title: Validator 7
testCases.testOut: No, 111 is not a Disarium Number.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given an integer, n, you must discern if it is a Disarium Number.

Disarium Numbers are numbers where the sum of each digit raised to the power of its place in the number (read from left to right) is equal to the number itself.

An example of this is the number 135:

There is a 1 in the first place.
There is a 3 in the second place.
There is a 5 in the third place.

(1^1 + 3^2 + 5^3) = 135
Input
Line 1: An integer, n.
Output
Line 1: Either Yes, n is a Disarium Number. or No, n is not a Disarium Number.
Constraints
0 < n <= 10,000
Example
Input
1
Output
Yes, 1 is a Disarium Number.
